title: The Wharf-Boat on the Ohio River at Cincinnati

location.subject: Ohio River wharf boat scene at Cincinnati's Public Landing
location.neighborhood: Cincinnati riverfront and Public Landing area

viewpoint.description: View of a floating wharf boat on the Ohio River at Cincinnati, showing the essential infrastructure for steamboat commerce and river transportation during the height of the steamboat era

technical.dimensions: Typical Harper's Weekly illustration size, approximately 9" x 13"

historicalContext.event: Peak of Ohio River steamboat commerce and river transportation
historicalContext.significance: Documents the crucial role of wharf boats in Ohio River commerce. These floating landing structures were essential infrastructure that allowed steamboats to dock and transfer passengers and cargo regardless of fluctuating river levels. Created during the golden age of steamboat travel (1860s-1870s) when Cincinnati was a major river port and gateway to the West.

verification.source: Harper's Weekly June 12, 1869 and Clark Art Institute collection

description: Historic 1869 wood engraving by Jacob Gervis published in Harper's Weekly on June 12, 1869, depicting a wharf boat on the Ohio River at Cincinnati. The illustration captures an essential piece of 19th-century river infrastructure - the floating wharf boat that served as a moveable landing platform for steamboats. These structures were crucial to Ohio River commerce, allowing vessels to dock safely regardless of seasonal water level changes. Created during the peak of steamboat travel, when Cincinnati was one of America's busiest river ports, this engraving documents the bustling maritime activity that made Cincinnati the 'Queen City of the West.' The scene likely shows the busy Public Landing area where multiple packet lines operated regular service to Pittsburgh, Louisville, and New Orleans.
